questions.question_text: When preparing a new IT strategic plan for board approval, the MOST important consideration is to ensure the plan identifies:

choices.C: roles and responsibilities that link to IT objectives.
choices.A: specific resourcing requirements for identified IT projects.
choices.D: implications of the strategy on the procurement process.
choices.B: frameworks that will be aligned to IT programs.

discussion.content: C. roles and responsibilities that link to IT objectives.
Why not C? Why not IT program align with framework?

comments.content: IT Strategy must align to business objectives which focus on value delivery to stakeholders. Thus D would be a better answer

questions.question_text: A strategic systems project was implemented several months ago. Which of the following is the BEST reference for the IT steering committee as they evaluate its level of success?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Operating metrics of the new system.

The best reference for the IT steering committee as they evaluate the level of success of a strategic systems project implemented several months ago is the operating metrics of the new system.

Operating metrics provide quantitative data on how well the new system is performing in terms of its intended functions, efficiency, reliability, and user adoption. These metrics can include measures such as system uptime, response times, error rates, user engagement, and other relevant performance indicators.

choices.D: Operating metrics of the new system

questions.question_text: The CEO of an organization is concerned that there are inconsistencies in the way information assets are classified across the enterprise. Which of the following is be the BEST way for the CIO to address these concerns?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Implement enterprise data governance.

Implementing enterprise data governance is the best way for the CIO to address concerns about inconsistencies in the classification of information assets across the enterprise.

Enterprise data governance involves establishing policies, procedures, and controls to ensure that data is managed consistently, securely, and in accordance with regulatory requirements and organizational objectives. It includes defining data classification standards, roles and responsibilities for data management, and processes for data classification, handling, and protection.

By implementing enterprise data governance, the organization can establish a framework for standardizing the classification of information assets, defining clear criteria for classifying data based on its sensitivity, criticality, and regulatory requirements. This helps ensure consistency and uniformity in how information assets are classified and managed across the enterprise, addressing the CEO's concerns about inconsistencies in classification.
